subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: Mongolia has not set a net-zero target. Mongolia aims to reach 20% renewable energy installed capacity by 2023 and 30% by 2030 – a significant leap from the 2018 share of less than 10%. The most important legal foundation was laid by the Law on Renewable Energy (2007), as well as the National Renewable Energy Program (2005-2020), which provided official targets and incentives for global investors in the sector.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Mongolia in October 2020 submitted its revised Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), which is a country’s plan to help achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement. It raised its target to a 27.2% reduction compared with the business-as-usual (BAU) scenario from 14% in the original NDC. This goal assumes significant international financial and technological support. The country also set an unconditional emissions reduction target of 22.7% by 2030 compared with the BAU scenario. In addition, the updated NDC included an optional component on forestry that would push total greenhouse gas reductions to 44.9% by 2030.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: Mongolia has no phase-out strategy for fossil fuel given the country’s reliance on coal.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: In 2020-21, Mongolia held its first renewable auction for a solar-plus-storage project funded by the Asian Development Bank. Due to the nascent state of the renewables sector, the vast majority of investment has come from international development banks or foreign entities. If the country is to meet its renewable energy target by 2023 and 2030, it will need an extra push for new investments in the coming years.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Wholesale prices for general coal generators are at 80.86 tugrik ($0.02) a kilowatt-hour, while the feed-in tariff ranges for on-grid renewables are as follows: $80-95 a megawatt-hour for wind, $45-60 a megawatt-hour for small hydro, and $150-180 a megawatt-hour for solar. This level is generally more attractive than neighboring countries such as Kazakhstan and China. Energy costs for users are higher than in nearby countries due to transportation and limited know-how in the local market.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Fossil fuels still account for 90% of power generation, though the share of renewables is slowly picking up. The power market is generally state-owned and the grid is regulated without any near-term plans for liberalization.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Grid-connected capacity is expanding, which should reduce Mongolia’s reliance on electricity imports from Russia in its western grid and from China in its south grid (Mongolia has four grids). Thus far, almost 100% of dispatch and purchase is secured for wind and solar by the only offtaker, the National Dispatching Center.

subsections.title: EV market
text: Mongolia has a very early-stage electric vehicle market with only 498 EVs on the road. The capital city of Ulaanbaatar set up its first EV charging booths in 2018 and the first EV fast-charger station in May 2020; there are now a total of five charging points.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The government has neither proposed any policy for a clean transport target nor has it set aside funds for grant or loan incentives to assist with purchasing an EV as of 2022. However, Mongolia in May 2021 announced that it would spend at least 420 billion tugrik annually in 2022 to 2024 to reduce congestion and improve roads with some provisions for e-bus and charging infrastructure. There have been some achievements by private companies in the EV space and the mayor of Ulaanbaatar has expressed interest in pushing this sector. At this time, EV owners only enjoy the luxury of being exempt from road use fees and are allowed on the capital’s roads without any restriction.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: One inherent barrier to Mongolia’s EV sector is the bitter winter and cold temperatures experienced during half of the year. These conditions can adversely affect the performance of EV batteries. The weather also limits the capacity for charging infrastructure: while it would normally take 15 minutes to charge with a direct-current fast charger, this could take two hours in Mongolia’s harsh cold. Additionally, the geography of Mongolia results in few inhabited areas along hundreds of kilometers of roads from one city to the next. This creates difficulties in building grid to support a lone charger in a desolate area. Lastly, the typical Mongol purchases an imported car that is usually more than 10 years old from Japan due to their lower purchasing power. It would therefore be very difficult to bolster the market for EVs, which are much more expensive.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: Mongolia has extremely harsh winters and high coal consumption, which has resulted in high frequency of chronic respiratory diseases, such as asthma. Heat pumps offer an opportunity to provide safer heating but there are currently no policies or incentives from the government that would aid in implementation. International development organizations seem to be pushing this sector, such as the World Bank’s low emission stove strategy, Asian Development Bank’s funding of a low emission heating project in March 2022, IRENA’s coordinated effort with the government to bring renewable energy solutions for district heating in the country and GIZ’s funding of projects under the Local Energy Efficiency Action plan.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The country promotes energy efficiency in its state and private sector and has a Local Energy Efficiency Action Plan.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: There is an apparent need for renewable heating solutions in Mongolia but there is no financial support in this sector highlighting the need for government cooperation and expanded international funding.

indicators.title: Doing business and barriers
indicators.question: Are PPAs (eg. corporate PPAs and all other types) signed in or indexed to U.S. Dollars or Euro?

indicators.title: Doing business and barriers
indicators.question: Can a C&I (Commercial and Industrial) customer sign a long-term contract (PPA) for clean energy?

indicators.title: Power market
indicators.question: Which segments of the power sector are open to private participation?

indicators.title: Power market
indicators.question: Does the country have a wholesale power market?

indicators.title: Doing business and barriers
indicators.question: Does the government influence the wholesale price of fossil fuel (used by thermal power plants) down through subsidies?

indicators.title: Doing business and barriers
indicators.question: Does the government influence the wholesale price of fossil fuel (used by thermal power plants) up through taxes or carbon prices?

indicators.title: EV policy
indicators.question: Does the country have a fuel economy standard in place?

indicators.title: Doing business and barriers
indicators.question: Does the government influence the retail price of gasoline or diesel up through taxes?

indicators.title: Doing business and barriers
indicators.question: Does the government influence the retail price of gasoline or diesel down through subsidies?

indicators.title: Buildings market
indicators.question: Does the country have a national energy efficiency plan?

indicators.title: Buildings market
indicators.question: Are there minimum energy performance standards for buildings?

indicators.title: Buildings market
indicators.question: Is there access to loans or grants for energy efficiency measures (i.e. Wall or loft insulation or double glazing)?
